title: 106_s1804
content: The Act is titled the "21st Century Technology Resources and Commercial Leadership Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. The Congress finds that the United States will need over 1.3 million new highly-skilled IT workers by 2006, with a shortage of qualified graduates in computer science and engineering fields. The number of technical science and engineering degrees awarded by US institutions has decreased since 1990. Foreign students received a significant percentage of engineering and computer science degrees in 1996. The US is a leader in technology development, but failure to meet industry needs may lead to companies relocating, harming the American economy. The purpose of this Act is to provide incentives for improving technology resources in the US to maintain leadership in technology and support the domestic economy and national defense. Congress has the power to regulate commerce with foreign nations and among states, which is crucial for the American economy. The Program is established under Section 3 of the Act to provide incentives for improving technology resources in the US. The Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with other agencies, will establish a program to enhance technology resources in the US for global leadership. Grants will be awarded to support the advancement of STEM fields in order to maintain competitiveness in commerce. Recipients of these grants may include business enterprises and organizations supporting mathematics. The Secretary will award grants to support the advancement of STEM fields for economic return and competency development in science, math, engineering, and technology. TEMPORARY SKILLED PERSONNEL IN MATHEMATICS, SCIENCE, ENGINEERING, AND TECHNOLOGY. In processing applications for visas or nonimmigrant status, the Secretary of State will prioritize foreign national students with advanced degrees in mathematics, science, engineering, or technology. Funding for grants is also provided. Funding for grants related to visas and nonimmigrant status prioritizes foreign national students with advanced degrees in mathematics, science, engineering, or technology. For fiscal years 2000 through 2006, a percentage of funds from the H-1B Nonimmigrant Petitioner Account will be available to the Secretary of Commerce for job training purposes.
